div.p: This paper proposes an optimal distributed control strategy for the coordination of multiple distributed generators in an islanded microgrid. A finite-time secondary frequency control approach is developed to eliminate the frequency deviation and maintain accurate active power sharing in a finite-time manner. It is demonstrated that the traditional distributed control approach with asymptotical convergence is just a special case of the proposed finite-time control strategy under the specific control parameter settings. Then, a secondary voltage control approach is presented to regulate the average voltage magnitude of all distributed generators to the desired value and achieve accurate reactive power sharing. The implementation of the proposed distributed control strategy only requires information exchange among neighboring local controllers through a sparse communication network. Simulations with an islanded microgrid testbed built in MATLAB/Simulink are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed distributed control strategy.

div.head: II. INTRODUCTION
div.p: ITH the gaining popularity in the utilization of distributed generation, especially renewable energy resources (RERs), the microgrid (MG) has emerged as a promising paradigm to accommodate the integration of intermittent components. High penetration and growing capacities of RERs poses many challenges to an islanded MG [1], [2], such as power quality, frequency/voltage stability, supply reliability, etc.

Hierarchical control frameworks, which contain primary, secondary, and tertiary control levels, have been widely adopted for islanded MGs in recent literature [3], [4]. To dynamically maintain the supply-demand balance without any communication channel, the droop control approach, which emulates the behavior of a synchronous generator, attracts significant attentions [5], [6]. However, the traditional droop control based approaches suffer from several drawbacks. Voltage droop typically demonstrates a poor reactive power sharing performance due to the dependence on output line impedance [7]. The secondary control level eliminates the frequency and voltage deviations caused by the primary controller and the tertiary control level mainly considers economic dispatch and power flow optimization.

The focus of this paper is to develop a secondary control approach in an islanded MG. The objective is to restore the frequency/voltage to the desired value and maintain accurate active/reactive power sharing among all distributed generators (DGs). The existing secondary control strategies can be classified into three categories: centralized [8], [9], decentralized [10], [11], and distributed control [2], [7], [12], [13]. The traditional centralized strategy requires central communication and computation units to collect and process the massive information of all DGs. These requirements may degrade the overall system reliability and suffer from single point of failure problem. Decentralized control strategy may not be effective to coordinate all available resources within the MG in an optimal way due to lack of broader available algorithms [15], [16], which enables all DGs to achieve a common goal through the peer-to-peer communication protocol. Due to the availability of renewable generators, MG's physical and communication topologies can be time-varying. To support plug-and-play functionality, the distributed control strategy provides a robust secondary control framework that works effectively in spite of time-varying communication networks. Moreover, distributed control strategies enable easier scalability, simpler communication network, and faster distributed data processing, which can facilitate highly efficient information sharing and decision making.

In [17], a distributed cooperative secondary control of MG using feedback linearization was proposed. It is assumed that only leader DGs in the MG have direct access to the frequency/voltage reference values. Through distributed communication among neighboring controllers, the frequency and voltage of all DGs finally reach their desired values. A distributed averaging proportional integral (PI) controller was proposed in [18] to eliminate the frequency deviations while ensuring accurate power sharing, but voltage restoration is not considered. A distributed-averaging-proportion-integral (DAPI) controller was proposed in [19], which addressed the adjustable tradeoff between voltage restoration and accurate reactive power sharing. However, most existing literature [12], [13], [17]- [19] on distributed secondary control provide solutions for frequency/voltage restoration and active power sharing with asymptotical convergence speed. Since an islanded MG may suffer from the sudden and fast disturbances caused by the intermittency of RERs and load variations, fast response control algorithms, and even finite-time convergence are preferred, which can provide robust performance and stability, disturbance rejection features in addition to a finite settling time.

To expedite the convergence speed, a finite-time approximate consensus strategy was proposed in [20], where the voltage control and reactive power sharing have not been investigated. A finite-time consensus-based voltage and frequency control was proposed in [21], but voltage regulation is still model-dependent with some considerable oscillations in active power response when subjected to load variations. Following this research direction, a few finite-time voltage restoration strategies were proposed in [22], [23], which designed the voltage controller independent from the frequency controller. However, the accurate reactive power sharing issue is not studied simultaneously.

To facilitate the decoupled design of secondary frequency and voltage controllers for an islanded MG, two control approaches with different convergence time are proposed. Firstly, a finite-time secondary frequency control approach is developed to eliminate the frequency deviation while maintaining the accurate active power sharing in a finite-time manner. Secondly, a secondary voltage control approach is presented to regulate the average voltage magnitude of all DGs to the desired value while guaranteeing accurate reactive power sharing. Only information exchange among neighboring local controllers through a sparse communication network is required for the realization of the proposed control strategy, thus it is adaptive, scalable, and enables efficient information sharing, fast decision making, and plug-and-play functionality. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy is validated by the simulations with an islanded MG testbed built in MATLAB/Simulink under various operating conditions.
The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

(1). An optimal distributed secondary control approach is proposed for frequency/active power and voltage/reactive power control in an islanded microgrid, which only requires information exchange among neighboring DGs through a sparse communication network;

(2). Finite-time convergence is achieved for frequency restoration and active power sharing, and it has been demonstrated that the traditional distributed control approach with asymptotical convergence is just a special case of the proposed optimal distributed control strategy under the specific control parameter settings;

(3). The scalability of the proposed distributed control strategy is investigated through a case study with the 42node distributed system. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the preliminaries of graph theory and closed-loop optimal control algorithm. The distributed secondary controller for both frequency and voltage control is designed with stability guarantee in Section III. Section IV investigates the performance of the proposed strategy through multiple case studies and Section V concludes this paper.

div.p: The diagram of the proposed distributed control strategy is shown in Fig. 2. The local secondary controller only requires reference values and information from neighboring controllers, using the peer-to-peer communication protocol. According to the proposed distributed control strategy, the frequency and voltage regulations can be implemented in different time scales. Thus, the design of active and reactive power controllers can be decoupled.

div.head: V. SIMULATION STUDIES
div.p: In this section, the effectiveness of the proposed optimal distributed secondary control approach is demonstrated through several case studies. An islanded 5-bus MG (frequency 50 Hz, line-line AC voltage 380 V) as shown in Fig. 3, which is built in the MATLAB/Simulink. The parameters of the DGs, transmission lines and loads are presented in Table I.

div.head: A. General Performance Evaluation
div.p: Initially, the conventional droop control strategy is applied to the islanded MG, at t=1 s, the proposed control strategy is activated, at t=2 s, an additional load of 1.5 kW+0.9 kVAr is suddenly connected to the MG and then removed at t=3 s. Before implementing the proposed distributed secondary control, the frequency and voltage magnitude cannot reach the desired value under the primary droop control. The frequency profiles of all DGs are able to converge to the desired value within a finite-time of 0.4 s, as shown in Fig. 4 (a). The voltage magnitude of DGs are regulated to be close to 380 V (±1.5 V) within 0.6 s, as shown in Fig. 4 (b). After applying the proposed secondary control algorithm, the active/reactive power can be shared close to the desired ratio in spite of load variations, as demonstrated in Figs. 4 (c)&(d).

div.head: B. Convergence Speed Analysis
div.p: In this study case, the comparison of the proposed optimal distributed frequency controller (31)&(32) with the one presented in [17] is conducted for convergence speed analysis.

For simplicity, only the frequency response mean square error (MSE) of DG 1 is presented for comparison. The result of Fig. 5 verifies that the proposed distributed strategy can achieve faster convergence speed. 6, which indicates that convergence of the tracking error is faster if ki is closer to 1 while slower if ki is closer to 2. Notice that, when ki=2, the proposed control strategy actually becomes the traditional asymptotical convergence control algorithm.

div.head: C. Impact of communication delay
div.p: Communication delay is unavoidable for distributed control algorithm which requires communications among neighboring DGs. Since communication delay may significantly affect the system's dynamic performance, the impact of communication delay on the proposed distributed method is investigated and compared with that of the traditional centralized method for two communication latency bounds of 200 ms and 500 ms, other conditions remain the same as those of Case A. The time delay is implemented by using a pure delay block e -τ(t)s in the simulation. However, as shown in Fig. 8 (a), the centralized approach fails to restore the frequency within 1 s before the occurrence of next event in the MG when the communication delay is increased to 500 ms. The proposed distributed approach still achieves acceptable performance with a communication delay of 500 ms as shown in Fig. 8 (b), which shows its advantage over the centralized approach.

div.head: D. Robustness against parameter uncertainty
div.p: To investigate the robustness of the proposed control approach against parameter uncertainties, the line impedances are perturbed with a random range of 10%-30% with respect to the values in Table I, other conditions remain the same as those of Case A. show that active and reactive power sharing can still be maintained with very small fluctuations. These behaviors are caused by the inaccurate estimated states due to the model uncertainties. However, the performances of active/reactive power sharing are still acceptable.

div.head: E. Influence of bounded control input
div.p: Due to physical limitations, controller with bounded input should be considered for practical applications. The control parameter ri have a direct impact on the dynamic performance of the proposed distributed secondary control, which are investigated in this study case. The value of ri balances between the convergence speed and the required control effort. Larger ri leads to slower convergence speed and smaller control effort. As shown in Figs. 10 (a)&(b), the frequency restoration time under the proposed distributed control approach with ri=1.5 is approximately 0.55 s, however, the control inputs exceed the boundary during the time period of 1 s-1.1 s. As shown in Figs. 11 (a)&(b), the frequency restoration process is completed with a longer time interval of 0.8 s when ri=3, but control inputs are maintained within the boundary and the ramping rate is also smaller than that of the case with ri=1.5. Notice that, the settling time provided in (41) is the upper bound of the convergence time, which is conservative, thus, the actual convergence time will not increase linearly with the value of ri.
From the above analysis, it can be concluded that one can easily adjust ri to handle the situation of bounded control input with ramping rate limit.

div.head: F. Plug and Play Capability
div.p: Plug and play is a technology allows new DGs to be added in and existing DGs to be removed out without any centralized supervision or redesigning the microgrid control system. It is desirable for MG to support plug-and-play functionality, due to the availability of renewable generators. The autonomous MG with five DGs and five loads is operating under the primary control at t=0 s, and the proposed distributed secondary control strategy is applied at t=1 s. An additional DG6 (power rating: 2.0 kW+1.0 kVAr, the corresponding line impedance Z16 is 0.08+j0.18 Ω) is suddenly connected at t=2 s, and then DG 3 is disconnected at t=3 s.

div.head: G. Scalability Test
div.p: This study case investigates the scalability of the proposed distributed optimal control with the 42-node distribution system [30], as shown in Fig. 13. By assuming the communication network to be the same as the power transmission line connections, the communication graph's algebraic connectivity is λ2=0.066. It should be noted that, the maximum tolerable communication delay depends on the eigenvalues of the communication graph [28], which are determined by the number of devices (scalability), number of communication channels, connectivity (refer to the way the devices are connected). Large system may have a small maximum tolerable communication delay, which implies that the scalability of a distributed approach can be limited by the communication delay to some extent.

The proposed control strategy is implemented using a neighbor-to-neighbor communication protocol, which enables efficient distributed data processing, supports plug-and-play functionality, and facilitates system scalable expansion. The proposed finite-time controller provides the frequency regulation and active power sharing be achieved within a finite time, which enables the decoupled design for voltage regulation and reactive power sharing at a different time scale. Simulation results demonstrate that the effectiveness of the proposed optimal distributed strategy in islanded MGs with unequal line impedances in spite of load variations and plugand-play operations. Future work will focus on the following four topics: 1) Investigation of priorities of DGs, since it might be more economical to control several important DGs in VSI mode, while controlling other less important DGs in current source mode.
2) Digital implementation of the proposed distributed control approach considering the communication package drops.
3) Rigorous analysis of maximum tolerable communication time delay for distributed finite-time control algorithm, especially for frequency control which is time critical.

4) Comprehensive study about the combination of communication delay and scalability, since the scalability of a distributed control depends on several factors, i.e., number of devices, communication topologies, communication delays, sampling rates. etc.
